fields.headline: Editorial
fields.bodyText: Cash continues to pour out of government coffers into local education authority and school/college budgets. There was a tranche of announcements at the start of this year, including a further £280m for e-learning credits to be spent on approved digital resources listed on the government's new online resources catalogue, Curriculum Online; a further £287m to give all schools a (fast) broadband connection to the internet; and £8m for online training of teachers. It's a significant budget for a vibrant sector now under Clarke's personal charge. There was also an extra £195m to get more laptops into teacher's hands ( the target is 66% ownership by 2006), which is a area covered in a five-page Guardian evaluation survey of laptops carried out by Teem (Teachers Evaluating Educational Multimedia). Be warned, though. The easier access is to the web, the greater the need among teachers to be aware of safety issues, particuarly those affecting vulnerable teenagers. Young people particularly enjoy the anonymity of teenage advice sites, of which there are plenty. In a trawl through some of the sites on the internet, Connie Loga raises some worrying issues and urges teachers to be extremely cautious before recommending sites. She also mentions several approved sites, including the relatively new government-funded Connexions Direct.
